articles.headline: 2 Vetoes Quash U.N. Sanctions on Zimbabwe
articles.snippet: An American-led effort to impose sanctions against Zimbabwe failed in the Security Council, with Russia and China exercising a rare double veto.
articles.abstract: An American-led effort to impose sanctions against Zimbabwe failed in the Security Council, with Russia and China exercising a rare double veto.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS  An American-led effort to impose sanctions against Zimbabwe failed in the Security Council on Friday, with Russia and China exercising a rare double veto to quash a resolution that they said represented excessive interference in the country’s domestic matters.

articles.headline: Woes at Loan Agencies and Oil-Price Spike Roil Markets
articles.snippet: Worries about the prospects for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and a run-up in energy prices made for a rocky day on Wall Street.
articles.abstract: Worries about the prospects for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and a run-up in energy prices made for a rocky day on Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac shares fell again Friday  and the broader stock market followed suit  as concern mounted that the government will be forced to take over the beleaguered mortgage finance companies, which some investors fear are at risk of default.

articles.headline: Can’t Find a Parking Spot? Check Smartphone
articles.snippet: San Francisco is preparing to undertake the nation’s most ambitious trial of a wireless sensor network that will announce which parking spaces are free at any moment.
articles.abstract: San Francisco is preparing to undertake the nation’s most ambitious trial of a wireless sensor network that will announce which parking spaces are free at any moment.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The secret to finding the perfect parking spot in congested cities is usually just a matter of luck. But drivers here will get some help from an innocuous tab of plastic that will soon be glued to the streets.

articles.headline: How Fallout Could Affect Main Street
articles.snippet: The swooning stocks of two giant mortgage companies have consumers wondering about the effect on those buying or selling homes.
articles.abstract: The swooning stocks of two giant mortgage companies have consumers wondering about the effect on those buying or selling homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stock market swoon over Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac this week has left many consumers scratching their heads, wondering if buying a home is a worse idea than it was seven days ago or whether to take down the “for sale” sign in the yard.

articles.headline: F.C.C. Chief Would Bar Comcast From Imposing Web Restrictions
articles.snippet: Kevin J. Martin’s recommendation is a strong statement in favor of network neutrality, the idea that Internet access providers should not be allowed to favor some uses of their networks over others.
articles.abstract: Kevin J. Martin’s recommendation is a strong statement in favor of network neutrality, the idea that Internet access providers should not be allowed to favor some uses of their networks over others.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators are prepared to take action against sellers of Internet access that want to restrict what their customers can do online.

articles.headline: Apple’s Toy, and Other Thoughts
articles.snippet: Thoughts about the new iPhone, an eye-popping, all-electric roadster and the self-serving gripes and paranoia of the Bear Stearns brass.
articles.abstract: Thoughts about the new iPhone, an eye-popping, all-electric roadster and the self-serving gripes and paranoia of the Bear Stearns brass.
articles.lead_paragraph: If I were a blogger, these are some of the posts I would have written this week.

articles.headline: iPhone Users Plagued by Software Problems
articles.snippet: Apple suffered network gridlock as the first buyers of the iPhone 3G tried to activate their purchases.
articles.abstract: Apple suffered network gridlock as the first buyers of the iPhone 3G tried to activate their purchases.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  For many people on Friday, the iPhone was the iCan’t.

articles.headline: Putting Their Houses in Order
articles.snippet: Difficult questions about the giant mortgage companies reverberated through Wall Street and Washington on Friday, with analysts disagreeing about what is ahead.
articles.abstract: Difficult questions about the giant mortgage companies reverberated through Wall Street and Washington on Friday, with analysts disagreeing about what is ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: Are Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac nearly insolvent, as some investors and policy makers fear? Or are the giant mortgage finance companies sound  and good investments, as others contend?

articles.headline: Worst Fears Ease, for Now, on Mortgage Giants
articles.snippet: After a stomach-churning drop in the stocks of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, officials and lawmakers managed to calm investors.
articles.abstract: After a stomach-churning drop in the stocks of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, officials and lawmakers managed to calm investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A day that began with a stomach-churning drop in stock prices for the two largest mortgage finance companies ended with a measure of relief, after government officials and lawmakers managed to calm investors worried about the health of the two companies.

articles.headline: Iraqi Shiites Reclaim a Village Razed by Sunnis
articles.snippet: Nearly two years after they fled during an explosion of sectarian killings, 60 Shiite families have returned to Al Etha in Diyala Province.
articles.abstract: Nearly two years after they fled during an explosion of sectarian killings, 60 Shiite families have returned to Al Etha in Diyala Province.
articles.lead_paragraph: AL ETHA, Iraq  Haunted by ghosts, the middle-aged farmer walked slowly through his home village, a place so devastated he had difficulty recognizing his own house among the ruins.

articles.headline: Expressing Passions (Just Not Your Own)
articles.snippet: When I mention that I’m writing a book for a doctor or an executive, I sense a certain discomfort, as if I’d said that I write term papers for a living.
articles.abstract: When I mention that I’m writing a book for a doctor or an executive, I sense a certain discomfort, as if I’d said that I write term papers for a living.
articles.lead_paragraph: BROWSING through the U.S. News & World Report list of “Best Careers 2008,” and secretly trolling for a hot new field, I discover to my surprise that I’m already in one. When I’m not writing articles or books of my own, I sometimes moonlight as a ghostwriter  an occupation that made its debut on the list this year, alongside careers like audiology, genetic counseling and urban planning.

articles.headline: Silence of the Lenders: Is Anyone Listening?
articles.snippet: Big lenders say they are doing all they can to help imperiled borrowers, but critics contend homeowners routinely meet roadblocks.
articles.abstract: Big lenders say they are doing all they can to help imperiled borrowers, but critics contend homeowners routinely meet roadblocks.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAN A. BAILEY JR. was desperate when he sat down on May 19 to send an e-mail message to his mortgage lender, the Countrywide Financial Corporation, pleading, yet again, for help.

articles.headline: McCain’s Conservative Model? Roosevelt (Theodore, That Is)
articles.snippet: In an interview, Senator John McCain called for a government that is frugal but more active than many conservatives might prefer.
articles.abstract: In an interview, Senator John McCain called for a government that is frugal but more active than many conservatives might prefer.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUDSON, Wis.  Senator John McCain in a wide-ranging interview called for a government that is frugal but more active than many conservatives might prefer. He said government should play an important role in areas like addressing climate change, regulating campaign finance and taking care of “those in America who cannot take care of themselves.”
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Michael Cooper

articles.headline: The Fannie and Freddie Fallout
articles.snippet: The mortgage giants gained huge advantages from unique arrangements with the federal government.
articles.abstract: The mortgage giants gained huge advantages from unique arrangements with the federal government.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT’S dispiriting indeed to watch the United States financial system, supposedly the envy of the world, being taken to its knees. But that’s the show we’re watching, brought to you by somnambulant regulators, greedy bank executives and incompetent corporate directors.

articles.headline: Protected by Washington, Companies Ballooned
articles.snippet: Helped along by robust lobbying efforts, the imperiled companies resisted stronger oversight as they expanded.
articles.abstract: Helped along by robust lobbying efforts, the imperiled companies resisted stronger oversight as they expanded.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Bush administration scrambles to address the sudden decline of the country’s two largest mortgage finance companies, some of their longtime critics say the crisis has been building for years.

articles.headline: Dissident’s Tale of Epic Escape From Iran’s Vise
articles.snippet: Free after years in Iranian prisons, a well-known dissident provides a rare window on Iran under its ruling clerics.
articles.abstract: Free after years in Iranian prisons, a well-known dissident provides a rare window on Iran under its ruling clerics.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  After three days on the run, Ahmad Batebi picked his way down a rocky slope to the stream that marked Iran’s border with Iraq. His Kurdish guides, who had led Mr. Batebi, an Iranian dissident, through minefields and dodged nighttime gunfire from border guards, passed him to a new team of shadowy human smugglers.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Warning: Habits May Be Good for You
articles.snippet: Social scientists have learned that there is power in tying certain behaviors to habitual cues through relentless advertising.
articles.abstract: Social scientists have learned that there is power in tying certain behaviors to habitual cues through relentless advertising.
articles.lead_paragraph: A FEW years ago, a self-described “militant liberal” named Val Curtis decided that it was time to save millions of children from death and disease. So Dr. Curtis, an anthropologist then living in the African nation of Burkina Faso, contacted some of the largest multinational corporations and asked them, in effect, to teach her how to manipulate consumer habits worldwide.

articles.headline: Treasury Acts to Shore Up Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
articles.snippet: The announcement of a plan to inject billions of dollars in loans and investments was intended to show the government would stand behind the beleaguered companies.
articles.abstract: The announcement of a plan to inject billions of dollars in loans and investments was intended to show the government would stand behind the beleaguered companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Alarmed by the sharply eroding confidence in the nation’s two largest mortgage finance companies, the Bush administration on Sunday asked Congress to approve a sweeping rescue package that would give officials the power to inject billions of federal dollars into the beleaguered companies through investments and loans.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Warns Wall Street: Stop Spreading the False Rumors
articles.snippet: The announcement, made before the markets opened in Asia, was meant to warn broker-dealers to quell the use of false rumors to manipulate markets.
articles.abstract: The announcement, made before the markets opened in Asia, was meant to warn broker-dealers to quell the use of false rumors to manipulate markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced on Sunday that it and other regulators would begin examining rumor-spreading intended to manipulate securities prices.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Jenny Anderson

articles.headline: Obama Girls Get Their 15 Minutes
articles.snippet: Senator Barack Obama finds himself on the tightrope that all politicians walk when trotting out their families.
articles.abstract: Senator Barack Obama finds himself on the tightrope that all politicians walk when trotting out their families.
articles.lead_paragraph: During the campaign of 2004, The New York Times  scraping the bottom of the barrel over a long Labor Day weekend  sent me to cover John Edwards’s vice presidential campaign. Right after I took my seat on the campaign plane somewhere in Ohio, all nervous and out of sorts, 4-year-old Jack Edwards came tearing past the Secret Service and into the back of the plane with a rubber knife, slashing the air and shouting, “I’m going to kill my daddy.”

articles.headline: In India, Magazines That Translate Well
articles.snippet: An explosion of Western magazines has hit newsstands in India in the past year, pitching a familiar mix of gossip, relationship advice and expensive goodies.
articles.abstract: An explosion of Western magazines has hit newsstands in India in the past year, pitching a familiar mix of gossip, relationship advice and expensive goodies.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Hairstyles to crave and hints on how to get over heartbreak. This month’s must-have lip gloss and a new nine-iron that will make your golfing buddies jealous.

articles.headline: Government as the Big Lender
articles.snippet: For millions of Americans, the government has morphed from lender of last resort into effectively the only lender.
articles.abstract: For millions of Americans, the government has morphed from lender of last resort into effectively the only lender.
articles.lead_paragraph: The desperate worry over the health of huge financial institutions with country cousin names  Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac  reflects a reality that has reshaped major spheres of American life: the government has in recent months taken on an increasingly dominant role in assuring that Americans can buy a home or attend college.

articles.headline: Lieberman Finds Middle a Tricky Path
articles.snippet: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman’s criticism of Senator Barack Obama has infuriated many of his Democratic colleagues.
articles.abstract: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman’s criticism of Senator Barack Obama has infuriated many of his Democratic colleagues.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Joseph I. Lieberman, lapsed Democrat of Connecticut, strolled into the weekly lunch of the Senate Democrats last Tuesday, unaccompanied by a food taster.

articles.headline: Pakistan Marble Helps Taliban Stay in Business
articles.snippet: The takeover of the Ziarat quarry has enabled the Taliban to turn themselves into a self-sustaining fighting force.
articles.abstract: The takeover of the Ziarat quarry has enabled the Taliban to turn themselves into a self-sustaining fighting force.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZIARAT, Pakistan  The mountain of white marble shines with such brilliance in the sun it looks like snow. For four years, the quarry beneath it lay dormant, its riches captive to tribal squabbles and government ineptitude in this corner of Pakistan’s tribal areas.
articles.byline: By Pir Zubair Shah and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: 9 Americans Die in Afghan Attack
articles.snippet: The worst attack against Americans in Afghanistan in three years illustrated the growing threat of the Taliban.
articles.abstract: The worst attack against Americans in Afghanistan in three years illustrated the growing threat of the Taliban.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Taliban insurgents carried out a bold assault on a remote base near the border with Pakistan on Sunday, NATO reported, and a senior American military official said nine American soldiers were killed.

articles.headline: Buy.com Deal With eBay Angers Sellers
articles.snippet: The golden era of the small seller on eBay, hawking gewgaws and knickknacks from the basement or garage, is coming to a noisy and ignominious end.
articles.abstract: The golden era of the small seller on eBay, hawking gewgaws and knickknacks from the basement or garage, is coming to a noisy and ignominious end.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The golden era of the small seller on eBay, hawking gewgaws and knickknacks from the basement or garage, is coming to a noisy and ignominious end.

articles.headline: Product Placements Acquire a Life of Their Own on Shows
articles.snippet: Product placements woven into the plots of popular shows are a growing concern to the Federal Communications Commission and consumer groups.
articles.abstract: Product placements woven into the plots of popular shows are a growing concern to the Federal Communications Commission and consumer groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the season finale of “CSI: NY” in May, the show’s characters gathered around videoconferencing screens to share information about a shooting. “She wants everybody on a TelePresence call,” says an investigator, Lindsay Monroe. “O.K., we have a full house, network’s secure, you’re good to go, Stella.”

articles.headline: Analysts Say More Banks Will Fail
articles.snippet: There is less danger than in the savings-and-loan crisis of the 1980s, but as many as 150 U.S. banks could fail over the next year, analysts say.
articles.abstract: There is less danger than in the savings-and-loan crisis of the 1980s, but as many as 150 U.S. banks could fail over the next year, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: As home prices continue to decline and loan defaults mount, federal regulators are bracing for dozens of American banks to fail over the next year.
